p.seg: Yu, en son temps,

se servait de cinq notes pour être à l'écoute du gouvernement. [聽治"conduct government" is unusual, 聽政 being close in meaning and much more current, but it is not rendered well by the entirely obscure English "listened to proper order". 許匡一 passes on the buck by just translating the words：凭五音来处理政务，as does 陳廣忠：用五音來处理政事，The translation "the five tones" "cinq tones", impeccable as it looks is not only uninformative but deeply misleading because it misconstrues the idiom. As we see, the tones play no part in what follows. Synecdoche is a category of rhetoric that is essential for comprehension of texts.
Il faisait suprendre les cloches et les tambours, les phonolithes et les clochettes,
et disposer les tambourins,
avant the recevoir les officiers des quatre régions
et de proclamer:
"Qu'il frappe le tambour, celui qui vient m'instruire du dao!
Qu'il heurte les cloches, celui qui veut m'éclairer sur la justice! [Yù is not "discuss"]
Qu'il agite les clochettes, celui qui vient m'informer des affaires!
Qu'il copte les phonolithes, celui qui veut me dire [yù CH] ses peines! [This is not yǔ "talk with".]
Et qu'il secoue les tambourins, celui qui a des litiges et des procès.
En ce temps-là,
on pouvait interrompre un même repas a sept reprises

et on pouvait recommencer trois fois à se lier les cheveux au cours d'un même bain. [§§§§捉髮"gather up his hair (to respond to a visitor)" is not addressed in the Western translations. 陳廣忠 gets the point：先一次头发要多次挽住头发. 許匡一 avoids the issue：洗一回头要被打断三次]
tellement on se faisait de souci pour le peuple de l'empire!
Qu'en agissant ainsi on ne parvint cependant pas à combler l'attente des gens et de bénéficier de leur loyauté.

révèle une réelle absence de talent. [§§§§§也"(then) this is because" is not recognised in the English and the "even" in the English translation does not fit the argument, quite apart from not being in the Chinese. 陳廣忠 puts this concisely: 是才能不够罢了。BH "then even talent was insufficient" is misleading: someone with talent is good and loyal.]
Sous les Qin
furent élevés de hautes terrasses et de larges belvédères
aménagés de vastes parcs et jardins clos,
tracées de longues avenues cavalières
et coulées de statues en or. [They were cast bronze statues, but none such have survived into modern times.]
On envoya des gardes sur les frontieres [HYDCD confirms these were border guards ，御覽八十六引作「邊戍」]
on perçut des contributions sur les foins. [芻槀 is tribute in the form of hay, 槀 probably not "dried wood" here]
Les taxes de capitation et les impôts sur les biens furent prélevés à plein van

et versés au percepteur des palais impériaux. [Shàofǔ is also a title "imperial treasurer" in Shiji. Whether this officer is referred to here remains uncertain. 高注“官名。如今司农。“ 九卿：秦汉以奉常、郎中令、卫尉、太仆、庭尉、典客、宗正、治粟内史、少府为九卿。But 陳廣忠 is plausible：搜刮的财物全部送入少府之中。]
Les hommes mûrs et dans la force de l'âge
partèrent vers l'ouest jusqu'à Lintao et Didao, la "Voie des Di", [§§§§§[至"as far as" is misunderstood in the English.]
vers l'est jusqu'à Guiji et Fushi, la "Pierre flottante", [§§§§§[至"as far as" is misunderstood in the English.]
vers le sud jusqu'à Yuzhang, les "Camphriers", et Guilin, la "Forêt des osmanthes", [§§§§§[至"as far as" is misunderstood in the English.]
vers le nord jusqu'à feihu, le "Renard volant", et Yangyuan, la Source du soleil", [§§§§§[至"as far as" is misunderstood in the English.]
où au long des routes et des chemins, leurs cadavres allaient emplir les fossés. [Not "on" but "along" the roads.]
À cette époque-là,
ceux qui par loyauté faisaient des remontrances étaient considérés comme indesirables,
et ceux qui suivaient l'humanté et la justice, comme insensés.
Puis, il y eut Gao, l'auguste empereur,

qui rétablit ce qui avait disparu et perpétua ce qui avait été interrompu; [§§§§§存"cause to persist" is misunderstood in the English. §§§§§亡"what has disappeared/is doomed to disappear" is misunderstood in the English. §§§§§繼"cause to continue" is misunderstood in the English. §§§§§絕"what has been/is bound to be discontinued" is misunderstood in the English. Predictably, 陳廣忠 has no problem with this current idiom: 使灭亡之国复存、断绝之嗣得续。]
il prôna les grandes règles de justice dans l'empire, [§§之"for" seems semantically important for the argument, but I am not saying anything... 待考]

et lui-même agita en personne ses propres manches, la pointe de son épée brandie, [§§§袂"sleeves" the concreteness of the image is not captured in the English. "Personally worked" gets nothing of the rhetorical drama here.]

pour que les cent familles obtiennent de l'auguste ciel son mandat. [§§§§§No! this has to be something like "for the benefit of the people beg for a mandate from august Heaven". The English does not address 命".]
En ce temps là,
des hommes héroiques, remarquables, eminents et géniaux se révelèrent au grand jour dans les campagnes et las marais; [This captures the style and meaning
Affrontant flèches et pierres à l'avant-garde,
et tombant dans les torrents et les ravins à l'arrière-gaarde,
un seul d'entre eux en revenait vivant pour cent

emportés dans la mort au cours de la lutte pour le pouvoir impérial. [§§§§§權"effective power" is completely misunderstood in the English “the balance of the world” which thereby misses the line of thought.]
c'était leur ardeur au combat et leur farouche détermination [cheng is earnestness of comitment and determination, not sincerity and honesty]

qui décidaient en un seul jour de leur sort. [§§§§§一旦"decided a fate decided on one single morning" is grammatically misconstrued in the English, and it seems that the French gets the drift. 陳廣忠：奋起武力激励威风，而来决定一时的命运。 劉康德 684: 奋发勇武精神，激励忠诚之情，豁出生命以决一死战。許匡一 is not as clear and helpful as the French：奋发勇武精神，激励忠诚之心，来决定一时的命运。Zhang Shuangdi limits himself to noting the rhymes and does not address the question how to read this, exactly.(p. 1408 note 36) This case is interesting.]
En ce temps-là,
ceux qui, arborant de riches toilettes et de larges ceintures, prônaient le confucianisme et le moïsme, [§§§§§道"advocate, support in words" is misunderstood in the English.]
étaient considérés comme des incapables.
Ceci dura jusqu'à ce que les violences et les troubles fussent vaincus
et qu'une grande stabilité gagnât l'intérieur des mers. [§§大"far and wide" is untranslated in the English.]

L'oeuvre du roi Wen fut alors poursuivie [§§§§§文"king Wen" is historically crucial and misunderstood in the English. 高注：繼文王受命之業。might of course be a misunderstanding. But 文之業 seems to work only in Gao's reading. Nonetheless, one understands why the English tries to read 文 here as below.]

et la gloire du roi Wu rétablie. [§§§§§武"king Wu" is crucial and not recognised in the English. §§§§§功"(military achievements" is confused with the notion of "merit" which is not relevant here. 高注：繼文王受命之業，武王誅無道之功。
On mit en pratique les plans et les codes des fils du Ciel, [The concrete reference of 籍 "foundational documents" is of great historical interest.]
le port du bonnnet de cérémonie des Liu fut institué. [Le futur Gaozu des Han (Liu Bang) le confectionna alors qu'il n'était qun petit magistrat sous la dynastie Qin.]

On réunit les confucianistes et les moïstes de Zou et de Lu [§§§§§揔/總"summarise the essence of" is not understood in the French or the English. This is an early formulation of syncretistic use of competing ducuments. The nuance of 總 here is important.]
afin qu'ils étudiassent les enseignements hérités des premiers saints. [§§§§§先"first, early" misunderstood in the English: not all "former" sages are 先聖]
L'étendard du fils du Ciel fut hissé,
le grand char utilisé [55:"Voiture officielle de l'empereur somptueusement décoré." §§§§§大路/輅，=玉輅"imperial vehicle" is misread in the English.]
les neuf bandes [des bannieres princières] instaurées.
On fit résonnerla grande cloche
et vibrer les tambours,
exécuter l'air Xianchi, "L'Étang universel",
En ce temps-là,
ceux qui voulaient agir par les armes éveillaient le doute. ["Were viewed with" is better. There is not even a mildly active mode here. The French is inexact.]
Ainsi donc, la même génération
vit se relayer les arts civils et militaires, comme le masculin et le féminin,
pour servir chacun en son temps.
Mais aujourd'hui, ceux qui se consacrent aux arts militaires dénigrent les arts civils,
et ceux qui se consacrent aux arts civils dénigrent les arts militaires,
si bien que, dans cette exclusion mutuelle, [§§§§文武"civil and military men" are not "supporters" but professionals.
nul ne sait plus quand il est pour chacun temps de les utiliser.

Cela revient à ne considérer les choses que sous un seul angle [§§§§§指"concept>conceptual aspect" is not here a finger pointing at anything. I suggest: "This is to notice (only) one single conceptual aspect of one narrow area." 陳廣忠：这些人都只是见到角落中的一指之地．却不知道八极的广大无边。
et à ignorer l'immensity comprise entre les huit extremes. [The addition of the notion of the horizon circle usefully moved into the translation]
Or, qui regarde vers l'est [§§§"And thus" seems to capture the connection here. Not "therefore".]
ne voit pas le mur qui se dresse à l'ouest,
et qui tourne son regard vers le sud
n'a pas de vue sur le côté nord.

Seul celui qui ne privilège aucune direction [§§§§§嚮"turn to>focus on" is disastrously misunderstood in the English as "incline". The point about focus is philosophically profound and hinges on a proper understanding of 嚮. 陳廣忠 seems to have got the point but is still disappointing. The French is philosophically very fine.]
embrasse toute chose.
Ce qui permet aux royaumes de durer,
c'est la possession du dao;
ce qui cause la ruine des familles,
c'est la perte du principe des choses.
Avant qu'ils ne conquièrent l'empire, Yao ne comptait pas cent foyers dans les remparts de son domaine,
et Shun ne disposait pas d'un pouce de terre;
Et avant de régner sur les seigneurs feudataires, Yu n'avait pas à son service une troupe de dix hommes,
Tang n'avait pas comme part sept lis carrés de territoire. [分 is not distribution here.]
Quan au roi Wen, il devint fils du Ciel bien qu'il s'établit à Qi Zhou, ["in the environs" sound better, but 高注：】紂治朝歌，在東。文王國於岐周，在西。
dont les terres ne couvraient pas cent lis!

C'est qu'ils possédaient tous le dao royal. [§§§§§也"that was because" is the main predicate, and this matters profoundly for the argument, as the French recognises. The French is sometimes loose but it is careful about the line of arguments.]
[王 "reing as king" is not "reign as true king"]
À leur apogée, Jie des Xia et Zhoù des Yin
partout où l'homme posait le pied
et aussi loin que circulaient les bateaux et les chars.
...possédaient des commanderies et des districts...
Pourtant, ils perirent de la main des hommes [Not "personall", "they themselves", "eux-mêmes".
et devenrent la risée du monde.

Car ils portaient les signes de la perdition. [§§§§§亡形"outward sign of imminent ruin" is misunderstood in the English. 陳廣忠：这是因为事先就有了灭亡的征兆。 許匡一：亡形：灭亡的征兆。形指迹象，即行不仁。 §§§§§也"this is because" is important for the argument, as before. 許匡一 provides an irresponsibly free but helpful paraphrase that explains what the available evidence was that allowed the prediction of what was about to happen: ，是因为不行仁义早就种下了祸根。 BH： Here the English transl. is highly misleading if I understand it correctly. It seems to say with better strategic insight Jie and Zhou could have changed their fate. (Fine point, Barbara! Illustrates the importance of our petty attention to detail!]

Ainsi, le saint observe les transformations pour y repérer les stigmates des changements à venir. [§§§§§徵"relevant evidence, available (early) indications" is not understood in the English. [not future verification, in this context]
car il n'existe point de vertu dont l'épanouissement ou le dépérissement [§§§§§"the flourishing an decline of moral potency"
ne soit annoncé à l'avance, comme par un vent précurseur. [§§§§§The English gets nowhere with this sentence. 許匡一 has it even more explicitly than the French: 德政的兴盛和衰落，事先都有苗头从风气上显露出来。
C'est pourquoi celui qui possède le dao royal

si petit soit-il, ne peut que grandir. 【§§§§§雖小"even if he is (originally) of slight importance)" is misunderstood in the English "though (initially) small" . Note that the sage is NOT always of unimpressive origin. But EVEN IF he is... ... §§§§§大"became great" is misunderstood in the English as a matter of past history, whereas the text is about philosophical generalisation and abstraction. [許匡一：所以实行“王道”的人虽然开头弱小终究会强大起来，]
et celui qui porte les marques de la perdition, [§§§§§亡形 is misunderstood in the English as above. There is consistency, at least.
aussi prospère soit-il, ne peut qu'échouer. [§§§§§雖"even if" is again misunderstood as factual and not hypothetical, which is crucial to the argument.
Peu avant que les Xia ne succombassent,
le préfet grand annaliste Zhonggu s'enfuit auprès des Shang
et trois ans plus tard, Jie périssait.
Peu avant que les Yin ne fussent défaits,
le préfet grand annaliste Xiangyi se rallia au roi Wen [§§§§§歸"rally to" is misunderstood in the English. 許匡一 has it right：归附了周文王]
et, l'année après, [le tyran] Zhoù périssait. [§§§§§乃"then indeed" is misunderstood in the English. ]
Aussi le saint, pour percevoir les traces de la conservation et de la destruction, 陳廣忠：因此圣人见到存亡的迹象、

ainsi que le limites du succès et de l'échec, [§§§§§際"decisive point" is misunderstood in the English. I suggest: "The sage's observing signs of impending survival or ruin, and the decisive point of success or defeat, by no means (first) in the Mingtiao wilderness (where 湯 attacked 桀 to found the Shang dynasty) or on the first day (of the hexagesimal cycle, when King 武 attacked tyrant 紂 to found the Zhou dynasty).]
ne s'en remet-il pas à la campagne de Mingtiao, les "Branches chantantes", [§§§§§[The English gets nowhere, does not even try to make sense of this in the context.]
ni à un jour jiazi. [§§§§§§甲子"first day in the hexagesimal cycle" is not recognised in the English. LeBlanc footnote 63: premier jour du cycle sexagésimal...symbole d'un nouveau commencement.]

Mais aujourd'hui considérant que la victoire appartient aux puissants, on se contente d'évaluer les terres et dénombrer les foules; [謂"consider" is misunderstood in the English, which gets nowhere with this passage. I suggest: "Now if one considers that the powerful will be victorious, then one measure territories and count populations; and if one considers that the rich will benefit (in the end), then one will measure grain and weigh up gold; and if that were right, then all rulers with 10 000 chariots without exception would become kings and hegemons, and the rulers with (only) 1000 chariots without exception would all get ruined."
considérant que la richesse dépend du profit, on se contente de mesurer les grain et peser l'or. [§§§§§The English fails to recognise the scope of the 謂 in the line above.
Mais alors,
aucun prince de mille chars ne pourrait être roi hégémon

et aucun royaume de dix mille chars ne pourrait être écrasé et anéanti! [§§§§§亡"be ruined" is mistranslated as "imperiled" in the English. §§§§§若此其易知也：The English does not recognise the counterfactual 陳廣忠 has it, but finds it difficult to make it quite grammatically explicit：如果这样想，那么千乘的国君没有能够称王称霸的，而万乘之君没有破国亡家的。]
Or, si les traces de la conservation et de la destruction [§§§§§迹/跡"sign (of what is to come, survival or destruction) is not recognised in the English.]
étaient aussi faciles à connaître,

même les gens les plus sots et les femmes les plus stupides pourraient en débattre! [§§§§§§The English does not get the counterfactual here either, which again is clearly intended though not expressed in the Chinese of 陳廣忠：存亡的迈象， 如果像这样容易知道，那么愚蠢的男女，也都能够辨说清楚了。and 許匡一：存亡的规律，如果像这样容易推断出来，那么笨男蠢妇也都能这样推论。clearly have grasped the counterfactual but fail to make it suitably explicit as the French does. But note that the French does not grasp 論"assess correctly" as the English does very well. BH: I would continue with something like "If the the traces of....were so easy to understand even...]

Le vicomte de Zhao, grâce a Jinyang, obtint l'hégémonie, [§§§§§霸"get to become a hegemon" is inadequately rendered by the English "preeminent". 攻金陽之城 "attack the city of Jinyang" is current in Han texts and one wonders whether "attack the walls of" would be the right way of reading that recurrent phrase. But I think the English has it right: the reference must indeed be to the legendary invincible walls of Jinyang. We do not, here, have the grammatical construction with the 之 of apposition.]

et le comte Zhi fut capturé malgre les terres des trois Jin. [§§§§§以"(even) with the support of (the territories of the Three Jin)" is not recognised in the English or the French. Zhang Shuangdi p. 1422 sorts out the history: 此三晉謂圍晉陽之智伯及所帥之韓、魏，非謂智氏兼有范、中行氏, against 陳廣忠 who misunderstands the old commentary: 智伯(? - — 前453 ) ： 智瑶。春秋末期晋国执政者。三晋：指智伯兼有范、中行氏土地。高诱注谓“ 智氏兼有韩魏＂ ， 恐误。許匡一 disregards the meaning of 擒: 智伯拥有三晋的地盘被消灭；For useful detail see 何寧 p. 942. ]

Bien qu'il disposât de la grande principeauté de Qi, le prince Min périt, [§§§§§以"in spite of disposing of (powerful Qi)" is misunderstood in the English which makes no sense to me. 陳廣忠：涽(min)王：战国齐君， 在位17年， 被楚将淖齿弑杀。]
mais Tian Dan, grâce à Jimo, acquit du mérite. [§§§有"get to have> gain" is inchoative, and this is not recognised in the English.]
Ainsi [I suggest: "Thus in the case of a state that is (bound to be) ruined,...

ne suffit il pas qu'un royaume soit grand pour éviter l'anéantissement, [...even if it is large in size that size is not to be relied on (as a guarantee for its continued flourishing) 許匡一：所以说一个国家要灭亡了，即令国土再大也靠不住；]
ni... si le dao s'y trouve pratiqué [...and when the Way is being practised (in a state)

pour qu'on le prenne à la légère. [Here is the beautiful French translation as it stands: Ainsi ne suffit-il pas qu'un royaume soit grand pour éviter l'anéantissement, ni petit pour qu'on le prenne à la légère. "...then even if that state is small it must not be taken lightly.]
D'où il appert
que la conservation réside dans la possession du dao et non dans la grandeur,
et que la destruction réside dans la perte du dao et non dans la petitesse.
Le Shijing dit: [詩云"In the Odes it says:" It does not seem congenial to speak of statements in these kinds of quotations from the Odes.
"[L'empereur d'En haut] tourna alors le regard [du grand roi Dan Fu] vers l'occident;
là était la terre qu'il lui donnait."
Ce qui signifie qu'il avait déjà abandonné les Yin pour s'approcher des Zhou.
C'est ainsi que le prince d'une principauté troublée
ne travaille qu'à gradir ses terres et non à fair preuve d'humanité et de justice,
ne se soucie que d'élever sa position et non de respeccter le dao et sa vertu. [The English "Way and its Potency", is more informative than the opaque French version.]
si bien qu'il néglige ce qui assure sa conservation [§§§§§釋"dispense with, leave aside" is misread in the English as "lose".]
pour créer les conditions de sa propre destruction! ["les conditions" is perfect]
Ainsi Jie fut il capturé à Jiaomen, la "la "Porte de la torche",
et, incapable de se critiquer lui-même pour ce qu'il avait fait, [§§§§§非"criticise; disapprove" is misunderstood as "negate" in the English.]
regretta seulement de n'avoir pas tué Tang à Xiatai, la "Grande Terasse".
Ainsi [le tyran] Zhoù se réfugia t'il à Xuanshi, la "Chambre des instructions",
et, au lieu de revenir sur ses erreurs,
regretta seulement de n'avoir pas châtié le roi Wen à Youli, le "Hameau de la baie". 羑 must be read yǒu. No other readings anywhere.

Ces deux princes disposaient d'un grand pouvoir; 【陳廣忠：夏桀商纣处于强大之势的时候， 高注 gives away the meaning of this but is disregarded by the French and the English：二君，桀、紂也。當其君也，彊大之勢，不能自知所行之非也，假令能修仁義之道，則湯、武不敢生誅之謀也。

s'ils avaient pratiqué le dao de l'humanité et de la justice, [§§§§§而脩仁義之道"But if Jié and Zhòu had cultivated the Way of benevolence and righteousness..."(CH) is another case where the English does not recognise an implicit and thus unmarked counterfactual construction, as above. If one fails to attribute this counterfactual to the text, that text makes no sense at all. The point is of great philosophical importance. 陳廣忠：假令能修仁义之道， BH yes; the subject are Jie and Zhou, not Tang and Wu as in the English trans.]

ni Tang ni Wu n'auraient eu à porter remède a leurs crimes; [The text seems corrupt. 許匡一22:这一句表达不太清楚。I lamely suggest "Tang and Wu would not have been sufficiently equipped to rescue them from any crimes." The English gets nowhere. 陳廣忠 does not make good sense：汤、武挽救自己的罪过尚且来不及， and 許匡一 has the same incomprehensible 來不及：商汤、周武王纠正罪过都来不及，]

des lors, quel complot auraient-ils osé diriger contre eux? [§§§§§何謀之敢慮乎"What plots would Jié and Zhòu have dared to make plans for (since Jie and Zhou were acting as model emperors already?" (We follow DC Lau who reads 慮 for the當 in the received text.) The irrealis is essential and unrecognised in the English, so that that translation is getting nowhere with the argument.]
Or, lorsqu'en haut la clarté des trois luminaires se trouve brouilée
et qu'en bas a été perdu le cour des dix mille peuples,

sans même parler d'un Tang ou d'un Wu, [雖微"even if it had not been for, quite apart from" is crucial and not recognised in the English. 陳廣忠 gets this across painlessly: 即使不是商汤、周武， 谁又不能夺取他们的政权呢？and so does 許匡一：即令没有商汤、周武王，谁个不能夺走天下呢？]
qui ne pourrait s'emparer du pouvoir? [高注：言遭人能奪之，不必湯武 "Anyone you meet in the street could take away their power, there would be no need for Tāng and Wǔ."

Ils n'ont pas cherché à réaliser la vertu en eux mêmes, [今"suppose now" is important here, and the word does not mean "Now" here, which would be 夫, I think. I suggest: "Suppose now that one does not examine what is in/up to oneself...]
mais à se protéger [de la justice] des autres. [...but on the contrary guards against what is in/upto others,..." BH: here the Engl. "searching for flaws " in oneself or others is possible]
Dans le monde, il n'ya pas qu'un seul Tang ni un seul Wu; [...then in this world there will not be only just one Tāng or one Wǔ." Such behaviour will call up many Tāngs and Wǔs that will replace one.
Quand un homme meurt,

For meticulous discussion see 何寧 p. 919ff. 待考]

Quand elle mourut , il porta le bonnet de soie cuite en signe de deuil. [As the French has it, I think the duke engaged in sartorial formal mourning for that "adoptive mother" by wearing a cap made of special silk.]

Ainsi naquit le port du vêtement de deuil pour les mères adoptives [§§§§慈母之服 "mourning garments to be worn in mourning for one's wet-nurse/adoptive mother" is syntactically misconstrued in the English. The garments are not for nurses.]

Le marquis de Yang tua le marquis de Liao et enleva sa femme. [§§§§侯"conventionally: marquis" is a definite rank, not like the generic "lord". 竊 is dramatic:"abducted" and in the English translation "take" seems weak, but is OK.]

Il n'y eut personne pour critiquer leur tenue, [§§§§§§§ 服"sartorial style" is the point here, the people not objecting to any of the ancient ruler's dress style. The English misses the point of the argument.]

tous embrassant leur vertu. [§§§§§同”equally, indifferently, as if their dress had been correct" Both the French, the English as well as the Chinese miss the point. §§德 is probably specifically "munificence". 陳廣忠：而共同含怀他们的德泽 also takes 德 as the ruler's "virtuous generosity" which makes more sense than the mechanical renderings of the English and French which do have the advantage of retaining a consistent version for 德.]
En ce temps-là,

le yin et le yang étaient dans un équilibre harmonieux, [§和平 is one binome, not two words. 陰陽"the (potential conflicting) cosmic energies of Yin and Yang" are what is really referred to here, not the concepts of Yin and Yang themselves, I think. 許匡一 has the subtle point precisely: 在那时候，阴气、阳气平平和和.]
le vent et la pluie s'accordaient avec juste mesure aux saisons
et les dix mille êtres proliféraient vigoureusement. [§§萬物"all KINDS OF things/creatures". What generalised over (rather than counted) are not individual items but natural kinds.]

On pouvait, en abaissant les nids prendre les corbeaus et les pies dans ses mains. [§§§§§§烏 “crow” is not 鳥，and §§§§§§鵲 is "magpie" and a magpie is not exactly an owl. I think the point is that the birds built their nests so low never having to fear that humans would cruelly reach down into their nests to take the eggs.]

et mener les animaux sauvages à l'aide d'une laisse de cuir. [§§§可羈"could be lead on a leash" has nothing to do with "ensnaring". I am sure that this is meant as a description of a paradisical ideal world (which is of course NOT meant seriously): but how does one prove this? How can one PROVE such poetic "light touch"? All one can do is HOPE TO develop a nose for such things through wide reading of creative literature.]

Qu'avait-on besoin de tuniques amples et de larges ceintures, [劉康德 brings Confucianism into this, where really only traditional custom is in question, but makes a useful point on the structure of this whole passage：以上用褒衣博带、句襟委章甫来喻指儒家礼教]

de revers d'habit, de chapeaux de soie et de bonnet de toile noire. [§§§章甫"ritual hat (attributed to Shang dynasty already)". 禮記,孫希旦集解：“章甫，殷玄冠之名，No insignia involved. (Incidentally: use 錢玄，《三禮辭典》to confirm such things, but 孫希旦 is also helpful enough.)]

Dans l'Antiquité, le peuple habitait les marais, et les grottes a flanc des montagnes. [§§復穴"earth caves"HYDCD:土窟。語本《詩·大雅·緜》：“古公亶父，陶復陶穴，未有家室。” There is no "again and again" here. The literary allusion is to the Odes.]

En hiver, il était accablé par le givre, la neige, le brouillard et la gelée; [霧露"fog, mist" is a binome, an idiom in HYDCD defined as "fog". It would appear that people were afraid of “attacks" from this "cold mist" as vividly described in 許匡一：冬天难以忍受霜雪雾露的侵袭。 待考]
en été, par l'éclat du soleil, la canicule, les moustiques et les taons.

Alors apparut un saint qui lui fit des habitations en damant la terre et en dressant des charpentes de bois. [§§§§§作"arise" is not recognised in the English. 高注”作， 起也”. Note that here the crucial role of the sages is indeed focussed, and the question is how general the scope is of this focus. 待考]
[lui fit des habitations]
La poutre faîtière fut montée et les pans du toit posés, [§§宇"eaves" seem to be lower parts of the roof, and are certainly not just generally "beams".]
offrant un abri contre le vent et la pluie
et une protection contre le froid et la chaleur.

Les cent familles y trouvèrent leur bien-être, [§§§§而"and thus" is disregarded in the European translations, but 而 is not semantically redundant here. I 劉康德 quietly adds "從此" to do justice to our 而 in the text:百姓从此得以安定. Similarly for 許匡一：，百姓因而住得安乐。One wonders why the nuance should be negligeable for European translators. §§§§§§安之"be at ease with" is not passive, as the French nicely recognises.]

Bo Yu fut le premier à faire des vêtements. [§§§§§§之"when" makes a subordinate temporal clause: WHEN he invented (proper) clothes, .... Neither the French nor the English recognise the explicit nominalised subordination.]
Il roula le chanvre de ses mains pour en faire du fil, [§§§§§索縷"spun the threads" is not translated in the English.
tint les fils de la chaîne avec les doigts d'une main

et y passa les fils de la trame avec l'autre main, produisant un tissu semblable à un filet. §其成"what he produced" 陳廣忠 renders this transparently: 织成的就像罗网形状. The English is legitimately free here, though not exact.]

Les générations postérieures inventèrent le métier à tisser et la navette, afin de rendre cette technique plus commode. [§§§§§§後世"later generations" is translated with a profoundly misleading added bracket "[of sages". Note that the later generations were continuing in the sage's tradition without necessarily being sages themselves. §§勝複：通＂ 滕椱"weaving tools listed in Shuowen.". The French does not address 勝複, but renders the final clause with beautiful easy precision.]

Le peuple put dès lors couvrir le corps et résister au froid. [§以"by this means"got to V (compare 可以"can by this means..."). §掩"cover", is not quite "protect". But none of this affects the argument of the text here.]
Dans l'Antiquité, on labourait à l'aide de socs taillés en pointe, [§§§§§耜"wooden ploughshare" is mistranslated as "stick".
on désherbait à l'aide de huîtres affilées, [§§§摩蜃 is literally , instrumental, just as 木枸 "sickles for timber": "with polished clamshells".]

on débroussaillait à l'aide de fauciles en bois pour ramasser du bois de chauffage, [§§§§§§木枸 "wood sickle" is instrumental and does not mean "with wood sickles they cut firewood". The apparent use of wood sickles to cut off small pieces of firewood I find interesting and worth pursuing. 待考
et l'on puisait l'eau à l'aide de jarres de terre cuite.
Le peuple peinait beaucoup pour de minces avantages. [利薄 "to (comparatively) slight positive effect"]

Les générations postérieures fabriquèrent charrues socs, herses et houes, [§§§§§後世"later generations, in later times" probably does not refer to sages: one would like to know if sages are referred elsewhere in terms of 後世In HNZ the reference is never to the sages in 18 examples. §§§§§耒耜"ploughs" and §§§§§耰鋤"hacking-and-levelling tool" are not recognised as binomes in the English.

haches munies de manche pour couper le bois de chauffage, [陳廣忠 reads 斧柯 as instrumental: 用斧去來.伐木 "and they used axes (instead of wood sickles) to fell trees", but the reference 樵 is "cut firewood" and not "fell trees".]
levier à bascule pour puiser l'eau. ["Drew water by the use of well-sweeps".]
Le peuple obtint de grandes avantages sans s'épuiser à la tache. [The French makes the point of this explicit.]
Dans l'Antiquité, les grands fleuves et les vallées célèbres [§§§§谷"valleys" are misread as "waterways" in the English. Valleys often have waterways in them but are not themselves waterways.]
coupaient les voies de communication

et faisaient obstacle à la circulation. [不通"one could not, reaching conveniently" is probably misread as "impeded" in the English, and 劉康德 plausibly avoids speaking of any act of "impeding": 人们交往不方便.]

Alors on se servit de troncs d'arbre évidés et de madriers [§§§§§為"produced/invented" is crucial for the line of argument in this sequence and it is not recognised in the English. §§§方"linked" (standardly glossed 并 in classical texts) is misinterpreted as "squared" in the English.]

pour construire des trains de bateaux. [§§§§§舟"means of water transport" is not explicitly a "raft", §§航"combi-ship" is defined 高誘注：“舟相連爲航也。”, but the English may still be right in dismissing this gloss here, because 舟航 is a recurrent generic binome referring to boats or ships that does recur even in HNZ.]
Ainsi, quelle que fut leur situation géographique [The French is neatly inferior at this point to the thoughtful English.]

les diverses régions échangèrent leurs produits grâce à ce nouveau moyen de transport. [§相委輸"transport to each other" is not addressed properly in the misleading and garbled English "exchanged and transported".]
Puis, on fit des chaussures en cuir souple grâce auxquelles on pouvait parcourir de mille lis. [§§§§靼"soft leather" is not "hides". §千里 is playfully hyperbolic as the French smoothly suggests.]

Le portage de lourds fardeaux sur les épaules écrasait le peuple [§§§§§§肩"shoulder" is not 背"their backs". §§§§§之"subordinating particle: as the carrying of loads on one's shoulders needed stressful effort..." is not addressed in the English.]

On inventa alors des roues en recourbant le bois et des voitures [§§§作"adverbial: as an innovation" remains highly problematic. Interestingly, 何寧 916 pays no attention to the grammatical details of of this either. The question remains whether the inventors are generically "the people" as the French will have it, or if we do have to understand the sages to continue here as grammatical subjects. 待考]
attelés à des cheveaux ou des boeufs, [§§牛"water buffalo" specifies neither sex nor state of castration of the animal, and is distinct from the other bovines.]
et le peuple put se rendre au loin sans fatigue.

Les oiseaux de proie et les bêtes sauvages causaient des blessures graves et le people ne savait comment s'en défendre; [§§§§§§The distinction between 禽 and 獸 is not addressed by the English as it usefully is in the French.]
on inventa des armes en dondant le métal [One would expect 為之作.
[...on inventa des armes... §兵刃"aggressive weapons" in one compound with a generalised meaning. The English "weapons and arms" seems disingenious.

Les bêtes sauvages des lors ne furent plus en état de nuire. [§猛"fierce, aggressive", is carelessly left untranslated in the English. §為害"do harm" should perhaps be distinguished from something like 害之"harm them".]

Ainsi, pressé par les difficultés, le peuple cherche ce qui favorise sa subsistance; [§§§§§§民迫其難"when the people are oppressed by difficulties" is crucial for its generality, and the subject "people" of the Chinese is omitted in the English, which very seriously distorts the argument of this passage by adding the bracket "[the sages"]. 許匡一 translates correctly what he sees：所以人民被艰难逼迫就要寻求方便的办法. The French, in addition, recognises the new generalising mode of the discourse, using present tense to mark the non-historical mode of this summarising conclusion.

contraint par l'adversité il crée ce qui répond à ses besoins. [§困"troubled by" is not properly dealt with by the English "bound" which seems to translate 綑 for which there is no evidence in the editions I have seen.]

Chacun s'appuie sur ces connaissances [§§§§§§人"generic: 'man'" is seriously misunderstood as referring to some concrete individuals in the past "the people", a reading that is unidiomatic (if not grammatically impossible) in classical Chinese. §§§§人各以其知"Man, each using his (own) knowledge" is without reference to the sages as suggested by the English "[from the sage]". In 各以其知 the 各 and 其 must be co-referential. (See the 43 examples registered so far for this in TLS. In any case, the Chinese translators I have seen all take it this way. The matter is philosophically crucial. 許匡一 is representative: ，人们各自凭自己的聪明才智. The failure of the English to respect this distorts the argument that is being made here. And this happens to be a core argument of the chapter.

pour éloigner ce qui lui est nuisible [§§§§§其所害"what they regard as harmful" is misconstrued in the English and in the French. 劉康德does not address the grammar：去避开有害的东西， 趋于有益的东西。許匡一 likewise: 避开有害的，靠近有利的. But, in this case no great harm is done for the 思路 of the passage, but the more complex putative classical Chinese is decisively more philosophically precise in the context!]

et pour approcher ce qui lui est profitable. [§§§§§其所利"what they regard as profitable to them" is carelessly misconstrued in the English and in the French. Interestingly, 許匡一 misconstrues the Chinese as well: ，避开有害的，靠近有利的。 陳廣忠 fares no better: 去进免遇到的祸害，而靠近对他们有利的事情己。 Nor does 劉康德：去避开有害的东西， 趋于有益的东西。 One begins to wonder whether we, as grammarians, have always completely misunderstood the function of 所 as an object-pronoun which always has to make the verb which it precedes transitive. However, the reading that grammar yields is manifestly more philosophically relevant than the translators' meaning which does not try to address the grammar of the Chinese. It does look as if grammarians have it right.]

S'il est impossible des suivre les usages anciens [§§§§§不可循"must not be followed" is misinterpreted by the English: the tragic fact is that often one CAN mechanically follow constant ancient models, and the trouble is that Confucianists DO recommend following such constant standards. The English misconstrues the very essence of the message of this passage. And the fact that the French in this instance do no better is no excuse. Fascinatingly, the Chinese translators feel they have no problem whatever here, because they can be innocently vague on the philosophically crucial distinction. 許匡一：既然常规不可遵循， 陳廣忠：因此常规不能一成不变去依循， 劉康德：既然常规老套不能死守. This is all very exciting and needs further discussion. 待考]

et de s'appuyer sur les instruments de l'Antiquité, [§§§§§器械 "contraptions" is generalising: "and if mechanical contraptions cannot be (continuously) relied upon" and does not refer specifically to "martial instruments". From a lexical point of view there is nothing "martial" in the concept of 器械 §§§也"factive: since, given that (>it having been established above that)" is probably not conditional but rather factive (assuming the truth of the protasis or antecedent) and deriving from it the apodosis introduced by 則.]

comment s'étonner qu'il faille changer et transformer les lois et les mesures des premiers rois. [§§§§§§有 "in some cases" is important for the argument, and there is no "must be" in the Chinese. The point is that, historically, some "have been" adjusted. §§§§則"then it follows" links two subordinate clauses to one apodosis which concludes from the impossibilities in the two conditional clauses, that there must have occurred changes.]

Ainsi fut abrogé le cérémonial prescrivant que l'épouse tînt le plat de nourriture lorsque l'époux présentait le vin aux grand banquets sacrificiels. [§§§§ 廢"exclude, ban" is not to politely "excuse": what is excluded or abandoned is the originally prescribed ritual presence not "of women", but of the ruler's wife, as the French takes care to elaborate. 夫人"wife; widow" cannot be used generically for "women" as the English assumes.]
Quand les règles des anciens rois
ne convienent plus, on les abroge;

quand les pratiques des âges récents [§§末"the latest" are not just any later ages. I suggest "And when it comes to projects these latter-day times," 事 are undertakings, political projects, official tasks, not really general practices, I would suggest.

sont bonnes, on les accepte. [著is tricky. I suggest "as long as they were good these they celebrated (along with the immutably famous exploits from the time of the Early Kings)." 陳廣忠 is loose on this, but seems to take this the same way: 末世出色的政绩，也要让它显明。]
C'est pourquoi les saints régirent les rites et la musique,

Ainsi les rites et la musique ne sont jamais immuables. [未始 "never ever" is idiomatic and should not be translated literally. The "ainsi" (thus) in the French captures the force of 是故 much better than any "therefore"]
mais ne furent pas régis par les rites et la musique.
S'il est une constante dans le gouvernement,
c'est de considérer le ben-être du peuple comme la racine.
si l'administration et l'éducation ont un principe, [§§§政教 is not to be read as 正教。（HDC)]
c'est de considérer l'obéissance aux ordonnances comme l'essentiel.

Si l'on veut veut le bien-être du peuple, [§§§苟"if really; as long as" makes an emphatic conditional, not an ordinary conditional. on n'a pas à prendre modèle sur l'Antiquité. [§法“model oneself" is not to imitate, because it involves reverence or profound respect. §§§§不必is here “one does not necessarily have to".]

si l'on veut mener à bien les affaires [§§§§周於"be comprehensively helpful (to the task)" remains unappreciated in the English. §§§§苟 "if one really/properly" is again not captured in the English or the French. The ancient glosss is 誠 "truly".]
on n'a pas à suivre le passé [舊"old precedent" 高注 brings out the point very nicely:舊，常也。傳曰：「舊不必良。」]

[...C'est pour avoir refusé de modifier leurs lois...]

C'est pour avoir refusé d'imiter les époques précédentes [§§王"became kings" is inchoative here, as often elsewhere, and the "ruled" in the English does not get the dynamics of the transition from one dynasty to the next. §§ the English "and so suited their circumstances" is a gratuitous addition that is not in the Chinese text.]
Le saint change les lois en fonction des époques

et transforme les rites en fonction des coutumes présentes. [The French misconstrues the syntax of the sentence. §§禮與俗化“the legal rules get transformed along with current custom". The English misconstrues the syntax, since it makes rites the subject of a transitive verb "to transform".]
Il adapte les vêtements et les instruments selon leur utilité,
et établit lois et mesures, règlements et ordonnances selon leur pertinence.
Ainsi, changer l'ancient n'est pas nécessairement condamnable, [§§§§§§未"not necessarily, not in and of itself" is a crucial philosophical nuance not brought out in the English.]

ni suivre les coutumes nécessairement louable. [§§§未"not necessarily" is not brought into the English. §§§§多"esteem highly/praise" is misunderstood as "excessive" in the English. 商君書：。然則反古者未必可非，循禮者未足多也。」陳廣忠 does not get the nuance of 未, but he does get the obvious meaning of 多"esteem highly, praise" right: 因此改变古制無可非议，而依循旧俗不值得赞美。]
Les cent rivières ont chacune une source différente, mais toutes se rejoignent dans la mer; [§§白川 is "all the rivers".

les cent familles ont chacune un métier différent, mais toutes contribues à l'ordre social. [§§§百 is "all the various". §§§家"thinkers" is anachronistically misunderstood in the English as "lineages of learning" and in the French as "families". But as Jens Østergaard Petersen has shown, 家 in contexts like these probably has to be taken to refer to (specialised) thinkers rather than schools. Cf. modern Mandarin 方家 "specialist".]

Pour admirables que soient les enseignements du Shijing et du Chunqiu, [顧遷：雖然是学问中的上等 ; 陳廣忠：《诗》、《春秋》． 都是学问中精美的东西，§§§§學之美者"are the most splendid objects for the scholars" is misconstrued in the English which does not try to address the grammar of the sentence. The Chinese translators see no superlative. Perhaps there is not necessarily a superlative but one might translation "among the most beautiful"? 待考。]
ils sont le produit d'une époque décadente. [§§§顧遷:但是 "but they are..." has an important nuance. ]
Les confucianistes s'en prévalent pour enseigner et guider le monde, [(and yet) the Confucians... ...]

Comment pourraient ils égaler la plénitude des trois dynasties! [許匡一：哪里比得上用三代盛世的经验来教导世人呢！The arguments seems to be this: "But how can these Confucians with the unchanging and uncritical cultivation of those ancient objects compare with the Three Dynasties and their willingness to change and to adapt to new situations.]
Or, si l'on prise le Shijing et le Chunqiu parce qu'ils représentent le dao de lantiquité, 如果认为《诗、》《春秋》是讲的古代的道理就贵重它们，

ne vaut pas celle où le dao était intact. [道其全 "orientating one's way from the period when the Way was completely realised.] [許匡一：不如称道更早的三王盛世的政绩。 does not reproduce the formal logic of the arguments although there is nothing seriosly wrong with it historically. (HYDCD gives many variants.)
Ainsi, l'époque où le dao se déteriore [道其缺"orientating one's way from the period when the Way was defective" . 許匡一：与其称道反映王道残破的《诗》、《春秋》，

réciter les écrits des premiers rois [§§§§§§先王 "the early/first kings" are misunderstood as any "former kings" in the English. §§§§§ 先王之書 "the 尚書 from/about the early kings. 許匡一：诵读三王的《书》。（王念孙认为＂《诗》”是衍文。 DC Lau omits the 詩 which is missing in many early editions.）For the logic of the argument the 詩 may feel as required and may have been inserted later for that reason.]
ne vaut pas l'écoute de leurs paroles;
écouter leurs paroles [§The "and attaining" in the English is superfluous.]

ne vaut pas d'atteindre la source de leurs paroles; [§§§§§其所以言"that which motivated their speech" is not just their subject or "that about which they spoke". The English translation does not address the grammar of the sentence. 其所以言 (which is, of course, quite different from 所言 which COULD come to mean "that about which they spoke". 許匡一：；听三王说的话，不如得知他们说话的根据。劉康德 also addresses the grammatical structure, as does the French：与其听他们的言论，不如了解他们说这些言论的根据理由。]
cette source, [§§§§§其所以言 is again seriously misconstrued by "about which they spoke" in the English. 高注：聖人所言微妙，凡人雖得之，

la parole ne peut l'exprimer. [高注 goes on beautifully：口不能以言。"he cannot express it with his mouth (with spoken words." §§I think, literally it has to go like this: "One who grasps what made them speak, will then still be unable to express this(弗能言) with words." The initial 言 is apparently "by the use of words". I do not understand the meaning of the English translation at this crucial point.]
le dao qu'on saurait exprimer [§§§§故"(associative and not strictly argumentative) thus" is not the conclusion of an argument, and this is crucial for a proper understanding of this text.]
n'est pas le dao de toujours.
Lorsque le duc de Zhou servait le roi Wen, [事"served (officially) under)]

il ne décidait de sa propre autorité [§§§§§專"on one's own authority" is an impermissible mode for those acting as subjects or ministers who have to act on the orders of their superiors. The "encroached" in the English does not capture the semantics of this. The duke of Zhou, in his administrative actions made no independent authoritative decisions/determinations of his own"]
et n'entreprenait rien par lui-même. [事無由己 "none of his official actions had their origin in himself". The English is less transparent than the French.]
Ses vêtements semblaient trop lourds pour son corps, [§§衣"here: (ritual) attire" is not captured well by "regalia".]
